THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 1, 1916.
GEOLOGY CLASS TAKES TRIP
Over 30 Men, Under Direction of Dr.
Swartz, Spend Week in Travel
Through Western Part
of the State.

From Monday to Saturday of
last week, under the direction of
Dr. Swartz, the 34 students of
Geology I were engaged in their
annual trip through the mountains
of Western Maryland.
From standpoints of both geological study and general enjoyment, the trip was unusually successful, despite the fact that for the
first three days the expedition
trudged over hills and hammered
out fossils in the face of a beating
rain. Thanks to the protection of a
rather varied collection of raincoats,
ponchos, and sweaters, the results
achieved during the first part of
the trip were practically as good as
those of the latter three days, in
which better weather was encountered.
Work was begun on Monday
afternoon, after a train ride of two
hours. The party disembarked at
the Clermont House, Monterey,
Pa., and there proceeded to make
a study of the formation of the
surrounding region. From this
point buses conveyed the men to
Waynesboro, where they passed the
night.
On the morning of the second
day, the party made the trip to the
summit of Pen-Mar. The view was
obscured by the mists and rain, but
enough could be seen to satisfy the
purposes of the excursion. After
lunch—eaten around a welcome
stove in a little cross-roads store—
the party traveled to Hancock,
West Virginia, and from there took
buses to Berkeley Springs. On the
road, a stop was made at a quarry,
at which many rare and beautiful
fossils were collected. The bathing
pool at the Springs had been especially prepared, and the men celebrated their arrival by a luxurious
swim.
The next day was devoted to
fossil hunting and to more detailed
study of the rocks of Western
Maryland. At 12 o'clock, the expedition took the train to Cumberland, arriving at the hotel in time
for lunch. In the afternoon an investigation of the surrounding hills
was cut short by the rain.
On Wednesday took place one of
the most important events of the
trip—the visit to the coal mines
near Frostburg. Here a representative of the Consolidation Mine
Company showed the men through
some of the mines, and initiated
them into some of the mysteries of
coal technique. The afternoon was
spent in riding through the mountains around Frostburg.
An especial hunt for the elusive
trilobite was the chief feature of
the following day, with a trip to
Dan's Mountain later in the afternoon. The view from this peak
is considered one of the finest in

Penn State to Have Hospital Corps.

A hospital.corps is to be added to
the cadet regiment of Pennsylvania
State College. Students preparing
for the study of medicine are organizing the corps as an auxiliary
to the military training department
that has been established at the college for the last 6o years. More
than 1,200 students, members of
the sophomore and freshman
classes, are given daily instruction
in military science, supplemented
by drills and maneuvers. Three
officers from the regular army are
in charge of the regular instruction.
Following the organization of the
hospital corps, Dr. C. E. Kennedy,
of college health service, will instruct the Penn State students in
first aid and field hospital treatment.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 1, 1916.
The Musical Clubs.

With their concert in Washington Tuesday night, the Glee and
Mandolin Clubs will reach the climax of the present season. It has
not been the custom to prolong the
time during which the clubs are
active later than the first of April,
but tempting engagements such as
the one to be fulfilled Tuesday
night have made it worth while
for the board of managers to hold
the men together for an extra
period of time, and results at the
later concerts have shown the extension to be worth while.
Beyond the limits of the two
hours in which the clubs present
their work to the Johns Hopkins
public at the McCoy Hall concert,
members of the University have
little opportunity to observe the
part, the musicians play in representing their alma mater. The audience to which the clubs play is
different with each concert, and in
the case of most of the town concerts is assembled through a desire
to hear whatever musical entertainment the men have prepared rather
than through -an interest in Johns
Hopkins student activity. In other

words, the clubs have no "following" such as that• which appears
regularly at Homewood to witness
the athletic teams in action, and
real interest in their work is confined almost solely to those who are
actually taking part in it, or those
who have done so in past years.
This is in large part due to the
nature of the clubs' work, and cannot justly be called an unhealthy
state of affairs.
However, it does rob the clubs
as a whole, as well as the individual
members, of a large part of the
credit due them for their sincere
work of representing the University. The impression created by the
musicians is equally as influential
in its sphere as is that of any other
major activity, and those men who
are persevering enough to gain positions on the clubs should receive
a greater share:of honor for their
attainment ,than that ordinarily accredited thelti.
The clubs of this year have done
their part, and THE .NEWSLETTER
.is very. happy to cOngratulate them
'on their achievements,. and to wish
them .greater success in their next
season. It is a, regrettable fact that
the nature of their work does not
seem to favor the bringing forth of
particular sentiment from students
unless that sentiment is founded on
unfavorable conditions, and we feel
that if the attention of more Hopkins men is drawn to that fact,
there May be a much desired
change of attitude on the part of
many who allow the 'years of their
connection with the University to,
pass without giving the Musical

support for the clubs, a well defined
step towards better conditions will
have been taken.

The Triangular Debate.

The victory of the 'Varsity debating teams last Saturday night
is doubly significant. It is significant in that, in itself, it was a distinct achievement-to defeat such
able teams as those sent out by
the Universities of North Carolina
and Virginia requires debaters extraordinarily well trained and well
prepared; but its true significance,
its greatest bearing upon this University's record and reputation, lies
in the fact that it was the third
consecutive victory of its kind, that
it makes this the third year in
which Johns Hopkins has been the
winner of the triangular debafe.

Fame may. come to a university
in two ways. It may come through
a high standard of scholarship, or

A Plea for Cultural Courses.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

As a student in this University,
engaged in graduate and undergraduate studies, I have found during
my stay' here a decided lack of
courses purely cultural; courses
which not only give to a man a
general knowledge of the subject,
but which likewise serve as stepping stones to more advanced work.
A Russian student, who had received most of his educational
training in Germany, remarked to
a professor of this University:
"What a number of uneducated experts you have in your country !"
Just as this European student
noticed the lack of a broad education in American professional men,
so do we notice the extent of cultural development in the average
European, and painfully feel our
lack of it when we are abroad.
The lower middle-class German is
better acquainted with the art and
literature of his own country and
the languages, history and geography of the world than is the socially higher American of superior
mental capacity.
It is especially deplorable that a
University such as ours, whose
reputation is as high in Europe as
it is in this country, should be so'
severely lacking in courses which
make primarily for culture. Students leave this University with a
doctor's degree in languages, possessing little or no knowledge of the
sciences, and with a Ph. D. in
science having, at most, but a very
superficial training in the languages.
A course in German conversation was a part of our curriculum
a year ago. No credit was given
for having taken the course, however, and today it no longer exists.
Graduate students who contemplate
travel abroad or association with
Europeans of culture in this country have no opportunity to perfect
themselves in foreign conversation.
Equally regrettable is the fact that
graduate and undergraduate men
leave Johns Hopkins with no
knowledge whatsoever of the heavens above them. That an educational institution such as ours
should offer no course in general.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 1, 1916.
GEOLOGY CLASS TAKES TRIP
Over 30 Men, Under Direction of Dr.
Swartz, Spend Week in Travel
Through Western Part
of the State.

From Monday to Saturday of
last week, under the direction of
Dr. Swartz, the 34 students of
Geology I were engaged in their
annual trip through the mountains
of Western Maryland.
From standpoints of both geological study and general enjoyment, the trip was unusually successful, despite the fact that for the
first three days the expedition
trudged over hills and hammered
out fossils in the face of a beating
rain. Thanks to the protection of a
rather varied collection of raincoats,
ponchos, and sweaters, the results
achieved during the first part of
the trip were practically as good as
those of the latter three days, in
which better weather was encountered.
Work was begun on Monday
afternoon, after a train ride of two
hours. The party disembarked at
the Clermont House, Monterey,
Pa., and there proceeded to make
a study of the formation of the
surrounding region. From this
point buses conveyed the men to
Waynesboro, where they passed the
night.
On the morning of the second
day, the party made the trip to the
summit of Pen-Mar. The view was
obscured by the mists and rain, but
enough could be seen to satisfy the
purposes of the excursion. After
lunch—eaten around a welcome
stove in a little cross-roads store—
the party traveled to Hancock,
West Virginia, and from there took
buses to Berkeley Springs. On the
road, a stop was made at a quarry,
at which many rare and beautiful
fossils were collected. The bathing
pool at the Springs had been especially prepared, and the men celebrated their arrival by a luxurious
swim.
The next day was devoted to
fossil hunting and to more detailed
study of the rocks of Western
Maryland. At 12 o'clock, the expedition took the train to Cumberland, arriving at the hotel in time
for lunch. In the afternoon an investigation of the surrounding hills
was cut short by the rain.
On Wednesday took place one of
the most important events of the
trip—the visit to the coal mines
near Frostburg. Here a representative of the Consolidation Mine
Company showed the men through
some of the mines, and initiated
them into some of the mysteries of
coal technique. The afternoon was
spent in riding through the mountains around Frostburg.
An especial hunt for the elusive
trilobite was the chief feature of
the following day, with a trip to
Dan's Mountain later in the afternoon. The view from this peak
is considered one of the finest in

Penn State to Have Hospital Corps.

A hospital.corps is to be added to
the cadet regiment of Pennsylvania
State College. Students preparing
for the study of medicine are organizing the corps as an auxiliary
to the military training department
that has been established at the college for the last 6o years. More
than 1,200 students, members of
the sophomore and freshman
classes, are given daily instruction
in military science, supplemented
by drills and maneuvers. Three
officers from the regular army are
in charge of the regular instruction.
Following the organization of the
hospital corps, Dr. C. E. Kennedy,
of college health service, will instruct the Penn State students in
first aid and field hospital treatment.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 1, 1916.
The Musical Clubs.

With their concert in Washington Tuesday night, the Glee and
Mandolin Clubs will reach the climax of the present season. It has
not been the custom to prolong the
time during which the clubs are
active later than the first of April,
but tempting engagements such as
the one to be fulfilled Tuesday
night have made it worth while
for the board of managers to hold
the men together for an extra
period of time, and results at the
later concerts have shown the extension to be worth while.
Beyond the limits of the two
hours in which the clubs present
their work to the Johns Hopkins
public at the McCoy Hall concert,
members of the University have
little opportunity to observe the
part, the musicians play in representing their alma mater. The audience to which the clubs play is
different with each concert, and in
the case of most of the town concerts is assembled through a desire
to hear whatever musical entertainment the men have prepared rather
than through -an interest in Johns
Hopkins student activity. In other

words, the clubs have no "following" such as that• which appears
regularly at Homewood to witness
the athletic teams in action, and
real interest in their work is confined almost solely to those who are
actually taking part in it, or those
who have done so in past years.
This is in large part due to the
nature of the clubs' work, and cannot justly be called an unhealthy
state of affairs.
However, it does rob the clubs
as a whole, as well as the individual
members, of a large part of the
credit due them for their sincere
work of representing the University. The impression created by the
musicians is equally as influential
in its sphere as is that of any other
major activity, and those men who
are persevering enough to gain positions on the clubs should receive
a greater share:of honor for their
attainment ,than that ordinarily accredited thelti.
The clubs of this year have done
their part, and THE .NEWSLETTER
.is very. happy to cOngratulate them
'on their achievements,. and to wish
them .greater success in their next
season. It is a, regrettable fact that
the nature of their work does not
seem to favor the bringing forth of
particular sentiment from students
unless that sentiment is founded on
unfavorable conditions, and we feel
that if the attention of more Hopkins men is drawn to that fact,
there May be a much desired
change of attitude on the part of
many who allow the 'years of their
connection with the University to,
pass without giving the Musical
Clubs a thought. And if that attention should result in bringing to
light any further means of active
support for the clubs, a well defined
step towards better conditions will
have been taken.

The Triangular Debate.

The victory of the 'Varsity debating teams last Saturday night
is doubly significant. It is significant in that, in itself, it was a distinct achievement-to defeat such
able teams as those sent out by
the Universities of North Carolina
and Virginia requires debaters extraordinarily well trained and well
prepared; but its true significance,
its greatest bearing upon this University's record and reputation, lies
in the fact that it was the third
consecutive victory of its kind, that
it makes this the third year in
which Johns Hopkins has been the
winner of the triangular debafe.

in two ways. It may come through
a high standard of scholarship, or

A Plea for Cultural Courses.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

As a student in this University,
engaged in graduate and undergraduate studies, I have found during
my stay' here a decided lack of
courses purely cultural; courses
which not only give to a man a
general knowledge of the subject,
but which likewise serve as stepping stones to more advanced work.
A Russian student, who had received most of his educational
training in Germany, remarked to
a professor of this University:
"What a number of uneducated experts you have in your country !"
Just as this European student
noticed the lack of a broad education in American professional men,
so do we notice the extent of cultural development in the average
European, and painfully feel our
lack of it when we are abroad.
The lower middle-class German is
better acquainted with the art and
literature of his own country and
the languages, history and geography of the world than is the socially higher American of superior
mental capacity.
It is especially deplorable that a
University such as ours, whose
reputation is as high in Europe as
it is in this country, should be so'
severely lacking in courses which
make primarily for culture. Students leave this University with a
doctor's degree in languages, possessing little or no knowledge of the
sciences, and with a Ph. D. in
science having, at most, but a very
superficial training in the languages.
A course in German conversation was a part of our curriculum
a year ago. No credit was given
for having taken the course, however, and today it no longer exists.
Graduate students who contemplate
travel abroad or association with
Europeans of culture in this country have no opportunity to perfect
themselves in foreign conversation.
Equally regrettable is the fact that
graduate and undergraduate men
leave Johns Hopkins with no
knowledge whatsoever of the heavens above them. That an educational institution such as ours
should offer no course in general.

Following the two contests with
Yale and Harvard, the nine lost to
Holy Cross College Wednesday
afternoon by the score of 7 to 3.
The game was marked by loose
fielding on Hopkins' part, errors
being responsible for every run
the visitors made. It was hard luck
for Phythyon, who for the 'Varsity
pitched a very good game.
Worthington again starred with
the willow, making two singles and
a triple out of four trips to the
plate. The game was very close
until the last inning when a couple
of hits, mixed with two errors and
a base on balls, gave the visitors
4 runs.
